subject: POLSH
description: In this course, students work on their ability to speak, write, read, and understand contemporary Polish. Students will also develop their intercultural competency. The instructor uses communicative language teaching with emphasis on structured input. Students use the textbook and workbook "Hurra! Po polsku 1" supplemented by Polish-English chapter dictionaries. This class covers chapters 0-9. If a student is not sure of his or her language level, he or she can contact the Polish instructor, Ewa Bachminska, at eb583@cornell.edu.

subject: POLSH
description: In this course, students continue working on their ability to speak, write, read, and understand contemporary Polish. Students will also enhance their intercultural competency. The instructor uses communicative language teaching with emphasis on structured input. Students use the textbook and workbook "Hurra! Po polsku 2" supplemented by Polish-English chapter dictionaries. This class covers chapters 1-10. If a student is not sure of his or her language level, he or she can contact the Polish instructor, Ewa Bachminska, at eb583@cornell.edu.
catalogPrereqCoreq: Prerequisite: POLSH 1132 or permission of instructor.

subject: POLSH
description: This course explores Polish literary works and their film adaptations.  Students will read excerpts of the canon of Polish literature written by Nobel prize winners as well as postmodern, controversial works.  Students will compare literary works with their film adaptations: from classics of Polish cinema to the 21st century blockbusters.  The class discussions are held in Polish, the readings are in Polish (with available English translations), and all films are subtitled.
catalogPrereqCoreq: Prerequisite: POLSH 1134 or permission of instructor.

subject: POLSH

notes.descrlong: Class will meet 3 times a week for 50 minutes each

subject: POLSH
description: Eastern Europe has contributed unique films to global cinema.  In this class, students will watch, discuss, and write a variety of films—thrillers and comedies.  Oscar winners as well as lesser-known films—from Poland, Russia, Bosnia, and Turkey. In addition to learning basic terminology, students will have the opportunity to become acquainted with the cultures, history and geography of Eastern Europe.  Students will write film reviews, analytic, and personal essays.  All films are subtitled.

For more information about First-year Writing Seminars, see the Knight Institute website at http://www.arts.cornell.edu/knight_institute

description: Eastern Europe has contributed unique films to global cinema.  In this class, students will watch, discuss, and write about a variety of films—thrillers and comedies, Oscar winners as well as lesser-known films—from Poland, Russia, Bosnia, and Turkey. In addition to learning basic terminology, students will have the opportunity to become acquainted with the cultures, history and geography of Eastern Europe.  Students will write film reviews, analytic, and personal essays.  All films are subtitled.

subject: POLSH

notes.descrlong: Prerequisites: POLSH 1134 or permission of instructor. Class will meet 3 times a week for 50 minutes each.

description: Students will master their language skills: oral communication, listening and reading comprehension as well as creative and formal writing. Students also deepen their cultural competence. Classroom discussions include issues of contemporary Poland and various aspects of Polish culture. Students have writing assignments and one oral presentation in class.
catalogPrereqCoreq: Prerequisite: POLSH 1134 or permission of instructor.

description: Eastern Europe has contributed unique films to global cinema. In this class, students will watch, discuss, and write about a variety of films: Oscar winners and lesser-known films, thrillers and comedies—from Poland, Russia, Turkey, Kazakhstan, and more. In addition to learning film terminology, students will have the opportunity to become acquainted with the cultures, history and geography of Eastern Europe. Students will write film reviews, technical analyses of films, and personal essays. All class films are available for streaming through Blackboard.
